question: What do plants produce that chemically weathers rock into soil?

content.source_1: Plant roots and decaying plant matter release lowâ€“molecular weight organic acids (such as oxalic and citric acids) that enhance mineral dissolution; this root- and litter-derived acidity is a well-known driver of chemical weathering that helps turn rock into soil.
content.source_2: Weakly acidic water reacts with primary silicate minerals (e.g., feldspars), transforming them into clay minerals and soluble ions; this acid-promoted alteration is a key chemical step in soil formation from bedrock.
content.source_3: The organic acids exuded by roots are weak acids that are readily buffered by soils; soil buffering reactions neutralize much of the acidity, limiting sustained drops in pH around roots.
content.source_4: Carbonate-bearing rocks (containing calcite or dolomite) rapidly neutralize incoming acidity and drive pore-water pH back toward neutral, curtailing further acid-promoted dissolution of more resistant non-carbonate minerals.
content.source_5: As roots grow, they exert pressure that wedges into fractures and pries rock apart; this is a mechanical (not chemical) weathering process and can dominate where chemical reactions are limited.
content.source_6: Quartz, a major component of many rocks and sands, has extremely low dissolution rates in weakly acidic solutions at surface temperatures; its chemical breakdown by organic acids is negligible on human timescales.
